content.description:
Fun arete action on decent holds to a crux topout. Safe and good. Continues to clean up very well.

I'm giving these boulders names, but please tell me if they have already established names.
content.location: The obvious arete in the middle of this boulder. start sitting, work your way straight up.

content.description:
Really cool cryptic line (at least for me it was tough to puzzle out). You'll notice when you come to the boulder some obvious holds on the left and a nice finish rail up and right. It may look obvious to you how to connect them until you step on the wall. Pretty tricky stuff.

The straight up looks good too - anyone know if that's been done?
content.protection: 2-3 pads - awkward landing, nice to have a spot
content.location: This boulder is a big shard standing up behind the UFO boulder on a higher platform. Start hands matched on underclings on left, and cut right hard. Then finish up and right on good holds, if a bit dirty.

content.description: The stand start to The Giving Tree. It's the original line on the boulder, before the Giving Tree was put up, before Land of the Free. Big moves on small, subtle holds on a steep wall. Steep movement on granite, it doesn't get much better than this.
content.protection: maybe 3 pads? Don't fall on the top out. It's onto a rock and pretty gnarly.
content.location: Start on the left pinch and right pinch/crimp thing. Shoot up left, and then up to the right slot. Grab slopers over the lip and top out.

content.description: Cool straight up in the middle of the boulder opposite the UFO boulder.
content.location: Opposite UFO, in the middle of the face. Start sitting, top out straight up.

content.description: The coolest line on the boulder starts on the end on the right, shoots up through holds to the lip, then cuts across the face to the left, and finishes on the arete in the middle of the face. Tricky towards to connect to the left arete.
content.protection: 2-3 pads to cover the ground beneath
content.location: The boulder opposite the UFO boulder.

content.description:
Gorgeous flowing movement up a steep, perfect, granite roof. Reminiscent of more famous alpine bouldering areas in the US. Spectacular.

Start sitting with hands on the crimp on the left, and small ball shaped hold for the right.
content.protection: I liked having 4-5 pads for this, since I backsplatted quite a bit. If you can flash it, or you like backsplatting, you may not need so many.
content.location:
Find UFO parking as described above.

Walk up the faint/moderately good trail, then slightly uphill, and notice the stunning engineering project of building this landing. Beautiful work everyone. I think it's probably saved a lot of damage to the ground here, as well as injuries to climbers.

content.description:
Crimpy power line on the left side of the UFO. Really good, but I don't like crimps as much as open handed holds, so it's not my favorite line on the boulder. That said, it is really good, and on great stone.

Start on the wide good crimp slot, paste feet, shoot up to a thin crimp, then a satisfying move to a glory jug at the lip, and a low/moderate difficulty topout.
content.protection: 1-2 pads. easier to protect than the others on this boulder.
content.location: Find the crimp slot on the left side of UFO, shoot up to the lip from there.

content.description:
The low mantle to sloper topout in the middle of this face. Fun stuff.

I made up names for the lines on this boulder, so just let me know what the real names are if they have already been named.
content.location: Opposite the UFO boulder, this is a fun mantle to sloper topout on the small wall.

content.description:
A gutsy little fella on the backside of the UFO boulder.

Start on low edges, then work up through big holds to a pretty high and committing finish over an imperfect landing. Might be worth bringing all the pads down there to do it. An unprotected fall from the lip could be gross.
content.protection: a few pads would be nice, I'd say
